ygData.subject: Cantera-1.3 + 1D flames
ygData.msgSnippet: Cantera 1.3 is now available for download. Among other things, it introduces the new capability to simulate steady 1D flames. Currently, burner-stabilized

Subject: Cantera-1.3 + 1D flames

X-Yahoo-Profile: dggoodwin


Cantera 1.3 is now available for download. Among other things, it 
introduces the new capability to simulate steady 1D flames. 
Currently, burner-stabilized flames are supported; other types will 
be added very soon. (They are actually already there; only the user 
interface needs to be cleaned up.)

The flame solver uses the Python interface, so to do flame 
simulations you will need to install Python 2.2 if you don't have it 
already on your system. Complete instructions on how to do this are 
included. (It's easy.)

The source distribution now includes the complete MATLAB and Python 
interface code, in addition to the C++ code, so you can build both 
from the source if you like. This has been verified to work using 
Windows and using linux, but should work on any unix-like system. (If 
anyone wants to port Cantera to Mac OS-X, please do so!)

For Windows users, there is also a binary version, which includes 
both the MATLAB and Python binary code. If you download this binary 
distribution, you can use Cantera from Python or MATLAB without 
compiling anything. 

You can get these files from http://www.cantera.org, as usual. Go 
to 'download', and then select the directory you want. For the source 
distribution, there is a zip file for PCs, and a tar.gz file for unix.

Documentation is still sparse, but tutorial scripts for both Python 
and MATLAB are provided that describe most of what you need to know. 
For flame simulations, see scripts 'flame1.py' (a low-pressure 
hydrogen flame) and 'flame2.py' (an atmospheric-pressure, rich 
CH4/air flame) in the python 'examples' directory.  

Please let me know if you run into problems installing or running 
this new version.

Dave G.
